instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-1987: What is 820-1987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message:
Prior to putting in DFU this board had liquid damage to LCD backlight area. That was solved and I could see cycling of power rails. I could see .8V on CPU rails cycling power briefly. So I thought maybe T2 issue. Was able to get it in DFU mode and have tried restoring the T2. It gets to 4th step then fans come on high and i get this error: 

The operation couldn’t be completed. (AMRestoreErrorDomain error 9 - Failed to receive message from device, might be connection problem with USB host. (Communication error, possibly USB disconnection)) [AMRestoreErrorDomain – 0x9 (9)]

Now it seems to be stuck in DFU all of the time. Now when i plug it to power it stops at 20.4V and 0 amps.  Prior it would cycle the wattage and amps but wouldn't boot. I'm not seeing any signs of more issues on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message: I don't have a donor to pull that from. Is that something I can find here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message: Or i have an old unlock Rom file I think for <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. I'm thinking that was should be good just no serial number I believe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message: Ok. I was able to flash the SOC Rom. It is still stuck in DFU. I tried holding power key down and SMC reset but it doesnt want to exit DFU and get the same error after attempting restore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message:
Try with both charger and (good) battery connected.
Also try with another USB-C cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message: Still same error. When I got this Mac it wasn't in DFU but has been apparently once I got it in DFU unable to leave DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message: Put back original SoC ROM and try again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message:
I can't remember what I did but I resolved the communication 9 error but it is still stuck in DFU but now giving this error when trying to do a restore:

Unexpected device state 'DFU' expected 'Recovery' (Probably forced into DFU mode externally) [com.apple.MobileDevice.MobileRestore – 0xFAE (4014)]

I saw on the boards someone that this error but they found issue on one of SLP2R lines. I did not find a fault. Mine are all good:

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.755v

PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE 0.802v

<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.800v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8v

<SIGNAL>PP1V25_SLPS2R_SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> 1.25v

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1v
 
I think I'm missing SSD lines but isn't that because stuck in DFU or no?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message:
Many times missing SSD voltages is solved by DFU.
Did you try reflashing <CHIP>U4770</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
threads.message: Yes I flashed it back the original file.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in DFU Mode
